note.p: While Ruskin did not subdivide his list into clusters, his intention is evident in that he drafted poems, which correspond to the titles, as an identically ordered sequence in MS VIII. (One cannot tell from the list whether its titles refer to individual poems, as drafted in MS VIII, or to proposed composite sections, of which those poems would have formed a part—the list providing no indication of intended genres.) The first title in this conjectural cluster, “Passing the Alps”, was drafted elsewhere, in MS IA, g.2, probably but not certainly prior to the MS VIII draft sequence.
As discussed in the contextual glosses for “Passing the Alps”, the planned sequence reveals the influence of Samuel Rogersʼs Italy, which (in the 1830 version) has this sequence of poems:

Comparing Rogersʼs sequence with Ruskinʼs, one sees that the younger poetʼs “Passing the Alps” serves the function of Rogersʼs “The Alps”, although Ruskin situates his poem as an introduction to the mountain‐pass sequence, rather than as reflective recollection, as Rogers does in his poem. In Rogersʼs “The Alps”, the narrator reflects on history, including Hannibalʼs crossing the Alps, which Turner made the subject of his vignette for the poem in the 1830 edition of Italy, and which Ruskin likewise developed as the topic of his poem. Rogers begins his poem with a reflection, however, which Ruskin separates out and makes the subject of its own poem—the first sighting of the Alps from Schaffhausen, celebrated in “There is a charmed peace that aye” [“The Alps from Schaffhausen”] (see the latter poemʼs contextual notes, for Ruskinʼs allusion to Rogersʼs lines in “The Alps”, commemorating the first view).

According to Ruskinʼs Plan for Continuation of the Account of a Tour on the Continent, his grand scheme was to place the topic of the first sighting of the Alps in one or both of two items, “Schaffhausen” and “The Alps”, which fall amid a sequence of items leading up to the Splügen Pass crosssing, treating sites from Strasbourg to Constance (see the contextual glosses for “Passing the Alps”). Most of these pieces were never composed, or do not survive, but in MS VIII he composed an untitled poem, which in its content clearly corresponds to either of two proposed items—“There is a charmed peace that aye” [“The Alps from Schaffhausen”]. In MS VIII, this draft poem immediately precedes the draft for “Via Mala”. Thus, in practice, Ruskin thought of his writing about the first sighting of the Alps as immediately preliminary to the writing about crossing the mountains, but he steadily expanded what Rogers treats as a single arc, with the narrator alternating between the time of present viewing and recollected time, both of his own recent past and of history and story. Ruskin tends, in contrast, to string out the narratorʼs experience as a succession of real‐time observations, each stage represented in a separate poem; and he attenuated that string of observations by adding more proposed sites for poems (or prose pieces, or composites) in that part of his Plan for Continuation of the “Account”.

“Our faith is on the precipice / How far far down those waters hiss / That like an avalanche below / Whirl on a stream of foamy snow” (MS VIII; Poems [1891]; Works [1903])—The Library Edition quotes from Praeterita: “It was again fortunate that we took the grandest pass into Italy,—that the first ravine of the main Alps I saw was the Via Mala” (Ruskin, Works, 35:116).

Ruskinʼs cousin, Mary Richardson, records that, after staying the night at Coire, the family rose early on 13 June 1833 to cross the Splügen, “one of the wildest and most beautiful passes of the Alps,” with the “Pass of Via Mala . . . the grandest of the whole” (Diary of Mary Richardson, 1833, 40). Similarly, in his 1838 guidebook to Switzerland, George Smith III taught British tourists to anticipate the Via Mala as, “without doubt or exaggeration the most sublime and tremendous defile in Switzerland.” The passage “commences about a mile above Thusis,” Smith explains, “and extends for a distance of more than 4 miles,” Mary adding that, on the approach to the defile, the “road goes along the side of the Rhine” and that, “a little below Thusis the lower and higher Rhine unite” (i.e., the Hinterrhein joins another tributary, but not the Vorderrhein, as Mary supposed). Then, as the traveler enters the canyon, she continues, “immense high rocks rise almost perpendicularly on each side of the Rhine (which is here a narrow stream) (Smith, Hand‐book for Travellers in Switzerland, 206; Diary of Mary Richardson, 1833, 40).

The feature in the scene that Ruskin adopts as his focus for his poem—the foaming of the swollen yet narrowly confined Rhine, “like an avalanche below” as the traveler climbs the precipitous steep above the river, its roar gradually “softened” to “Murmuring up from the profound / Of distance dark where light of day / Pierced not”—is explained by Smith: “It is difficult to give, with any precision, the dimensions of this gorge, which has cleft the mountains through the chine. The precipices, which often rise perpendicularly on both sides of it, are certainly in some places 1600 ft. high, and, in many places, not more than 10 yards apart. The Rhine, compressed within this narrow, stony bed to the width of a pigmy rivulet, is barely audible as it rushes through the depths below the road. The rocks of slate and limestone, composing the walls of the ravine, are so hard that they appear to have suffered no disintegration from the weather; the fracture is so fresh and sharp that, were the convulsive force from below, which divided them, again called forth to unite them, it seems as though the gulf would close and leave no aperture behind. When the traveller enters the mouth of the defile, the sudden transition from the glare of sunshine, to the gloom of a chasm so narrow that it leaves but a strip of sky visible overhead, is exceedingly striking” (p. 206).

Despite these terrors, the sublime experience was rendered safe for travelers in the 1830s by a road that provided, as Mary remarked with her usual chauvinism, a “surface . . . as good as any road in Great Britain” (p. 40). The new carriage road with a parapet, completed in 1821, is credited by Smith to an Italian engineer, Giulio Pocobelli (1766–1843)—although the honor may properly belong to his assistant, Richard La Nicca (1794–1883)—who blasted a tunnel through a “projecting buttress of rock which had previously denied all access. . . . The view looking back from this through the dark vista of black rock and the fringe of firs upon the ruined tower of Realt [Castle Hohen Rätien] and the sun‐lit valley of Domleschg is very pleasing.” Beyond the tunnel, “the road is protected by a parapet wall below which at a depth of many hundred feet the contracted Rhine frets the foot of the precipice” (p. 207).
